head.title: Our Thirst for Oil: It's Time to Cut Back

hedline.hl1: Our Thirst for Oil: It's Time to Cut Back

abstract.p: Letter by John Lynn of American Methanol Institute on Sept 13 editorial on oil prices; suggests Times support conservation, alternative fuels and new auto technology, rather than just calling for more oil production

block.p: ''The Latest Oil Shock'' (editorial, Sept. 13) is silent on what Americans can do in the face of $35-per-barrel crude, other than cross their fingers and hope foreign suppliers increase production.
''The Latest Oil Shock'' (editorial, Sept. 13) is silent on what Americans can do in the face of $35-per-barrel crude, other than cross their fingers and hope foreign suppliers increase production.
Fortunately, government and industry leaders recognize that Americans must break their dependence on foreign oil and the petroleum-fueled engine.

United States senators and representatives from both parties have introduced legislative tax incentives that will accelerate the commercial introduction of zero-emission electric fuel cell vehicles. The California Air Resources Board last week unanimously reaffirmed its intention to require 10 percent of all new vehicles sold in that state in 2003 to meet zero-emission standards.
Shouldn't you be supporting conservation, alternative fuels and this new automotive technology instead of just calling for more foreign oil production?
JOHN LYNN President and Chief Executive American Methanol Institute Washington, Sept. 13, 2000
